thread.title: PREP VOLLEYBALL: Brown's remarkable Good Hope career ends after 38 seasons
thread.title_full: PREP VOLLEYBALL: Brown's remarkable Good Hope career ends after 38 seasons

author: robk@cullmantimes.com(Rob Ketcham)
title: PREP VOLLEYBALL: Brown's remarkable Good Hope career ends after 38 seasons
text:
HUNTSVILLE — After 38 memorable seasons, the Rosemary Brown era at Good Hope has come to an end. 
Oh, and what a ride it was. 
Saturday's close four-set loss to ninth-ranked and defending Class 4A state champion Danville at the North Super Regional did nothing to diminish the head coach's undeniable legacy. 
Brown's career-high 52 wins this fall bumped her total to an astounding 1,030 throughout a fruitful tenure that also included 17 Cullman County championships, 21 area titles and 13 state tournament appearances. 
The finality actually started to sink in for Brown while the Raiders were warming up for Saturday's quarterfinal at the Von Braun Center. 
“I kinda thought, this might be the last time I'm on this court,” she said. 
Unfortunately for Brown, it was. 
No. 4 Good Hope (52-7) forced a fourth set with a gutty effort in the third but ultimately wasn't able to overcome an 0-2 deficit, falling 20-25, 23-25, 25-18, 23-25. 
The closing stretch was especially hard to swallow. The Raiders held 16-12 and 23-22 leads in the fourth set but saw each slip due to an assortment of unforced — and uncharacteristic — errors. 
“Those little mistakes are big mistakes when you're playing a good team,” Brown said. 
Kaylee Maddox shared her coach's assessment. 
“It was just the small things we don't usually mess up on,” said this year's Cullman County MVP. “It just kinda got us in the end.” 
Maddox never displayed an ounce of quit, racking up 27 kills, four blocks, three aces and five assists. 
The tears flowed freely for the senior following her final match — but it wasn't out of weakness. It had more to do with saying goodbye to a program that's produced enough memories and friendships to last a lifetime. 
“It means a lot,” Maddox said of her Good Hope career. “Especially just all the girls I've got to play with in the past and especially this year. This year was the best I've had.” 
Kate Kent kicked in 14 kills and seven blocks against Danville. Alyssa Harlan added seven kills and five blocks, and Hannah Smith had 29 assists, three kills and a block. Angel Baker chipped in six assists. 
Harlan, Smith and Baker rounded out the Raiders' senior class. Maddox, Harlan and Smith were varsity mainstays since their freshman seasons. 
Maddox and Smith will continue their volleyball journeys at the college level, the former at Wallace State and latter at Snead State. 
“They've been around a long time,” Brown said of her seniors. “Good kids. The best.” 
Maddox reciprocated the love for her coach. She said Brown has meant “everything” to Good Hope volleyball. 
“I feel like she's made it what it is right now,” Maddox said. 
Brown held her composure for as long as possible but finally cracked shortly after addressing her girls and sauntering away to add up one last batch of stats. 
Brown fought through tears while speaking about how representing the Red and White has “been a big part of my life.” 
Although she's done roaming the Good Hope bench, dancing and reacting with every point, Brown will, without a doubt, forever be a Raider. 
“Always.”
